section-block.rac_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Jennifer Ward Illustrated by Lisa Falkenstern
section-block.rac_book_summary: From its highest leaf to its tangled roots, this tree buzzes with activity. Animals search for food, branches sway, leaves rustle, and children play. Zoom in for a close-up look at a very busy tree.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about why animals need homes. Work together to identify the different places where animals live.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_1: Dance to the Animal Homes Theme
section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to dance to the PreK on My Way™ theme music to build excitement for learning about animal homes.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Busy Tree by Jennifer Ward and illustrated by Lisa Falkenstern.
Scout loves stories about animals. He especially loves stories about trees, because they remind him of his home!
I want you to think about a question as we read. We will answer the question after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do animals make homes in trees?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.

rac_d-hed_page_number.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at the tree. Does it look quiet or does it look busy?
Look at the chipmunks. They nibbled on acorns.
The owl lives in a hollow of the tree. A hollow is a hole. Does that mean that the owl lives inside of the tree or outside of the tree?
Look at the baby birds. They are called hatchlings. Birds build nests high in trees to keep their hatchlings safe.
This is a cocoon. Inside of it is a caterpillar, but we can’t see it yet. Soon the caterpillar will turn into a moth! How does the cocoon keep the caterpillar safe?
This illustration shows the same tree in different stages of its life cycle. What do you notice about the first and the last trees?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do animals make homes in trees?
section.rac_body-text: Give one moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Owls live in holes in trees.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about animal homes as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do birds build nests in trees?
How does a spider make its home in a tree?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children are curious about young animals and their metamorphoses. The Busy Tree shows organisms at different stages in their life cycles. Given time to observe the development of caterpillars and seeds, children will begin to construct an understanding of life cycles on their own.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Showing Curiosity
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion about a time children remember asking the questions “why?” or “how?” Help children understand that we ask questions when we are curious. Emphasize that being curious, or wondering why, is how we learn. Explain that if we can’t figure out the answer to a question right away, that’s okay, too. (MB)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for places to practice being curious as we revisit the book The Busy Tree by Jennifer Ward.
Clifford is curious about the animals in this book. He likes to focus on pictures to learn more about each animal.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages of the story as we practice our Mind Builder, showing curiosity by asking questions.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Focus on the illustration.
Describe what you see.
Do you have any questions about the animal you see? What is the animal doing? (MB)
These ants are searching for food.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Who can show me what it looks like when you are searching?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What animals do you see? These are squirrels just like Scout. What are the squirrels doing? (MB)
What animal do you see? What is the animals doing?
What do you think will happen to the seed the girl is planting?

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to pretend to be any of the animals in the book, as you play Red Light-Green Light. Create a starting line. Then explain that when you say “green light,” children can move around like the animals they have chosen and move toward a finish line. But when you say “red light” they must stop. If children move when you say “red light” they must go back to the starting line. The first child to reach the finish line will be the one to say “red light, green light” during the next round. Remind children that there is no running. Ensure that the area is clear before children start the game.
Transcribe children’s responses as they talk about different animals. Ask, Which animal lives in a tree? Which animal lives in a web? Which animal lives in a nest?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Showing curiosity is a key motivation and creativity skill. Four year olds naturally want to know why, and encouraging their curiosity is a great way to support their language and intellectual development. Answer their why questions as often as possible. (Ames, 1994)

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about words that are the same but have different meanings.
Hide the Scout Puppet somewhere around your desk. Have children ask where it is using prepositions. Explain that prepositions tell us where things are. Give examples.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book The Busy Tree by Jennifer Ward.
Scout loves The Busy Tree because he loves learning about other animals!
This is the question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What makes a tree a good place for animals?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The chipmunks are eating acorns from the tree. One chipmunk is under the acorn. The word under tells us where the chipmunk is.
What animal do you see? This animal lives in the bark of the tree.
The word bark is a multiple-meaning word.
Where else have you heard the word bark before?
These hatchlings are in a nest high in the tree. How do the tree branches help the hatchlings?
A bough is a tree branch. When they move, we say they sway.
Now let’s pretend our arms are branches. Let’s make our branches sway.
Did you ask questions as we read the story today? Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What makes a tree a good home for animals?
section.rac_body-text: Give one moment for Turn and Talk.
Then choose 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Trees have food for animals to eat.
Trees are a place for animals to live.
Trees keep animals cozy and warm.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about different animal homes.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What can trees be for animals?
Trees are a place for animals to l_____ (live).
Trees are a place for animals to live.
What do trees do for people? Why?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Story time provides an opportunity to build English learners’ vocabulary. Introducing two new words each day, organized around a theme, is equally effective for both English learners and native speakers. Help children make these words part of their vocabulary by encouraging them to use and reuse these words throughout the week.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead a discussion about what children have learned so far about animal homes. Discuss how animal homes are similar to and different from people’s homes.
To the tune of “The Farmer in the Dell,” invite children to sing, “The bear lives in a cave [repeat], hi ho the derry-o, a bear lives in a cave.” Create new verses together.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read At the Pond. It is a poem in the form of a poster.
Scout loves poems, especially when they rhyme.
The Busy Tree and At the Pond both show animals where they live. Let’s see if we can find any connections between the two!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show The Busy Tree book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question: What is it like where animals live?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to take turns responding.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can show me the worms?
Where are the worms? They are under the gr_____.
Who can point to the grasshoppers? Are they hopping?
Show me how you hop like a grasshopper.
Who can come point to the butterfly? What other animals on the Big Chart can fly?
In The Busy Bee the boy finds an acorn that the tree shakes from its top.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show page 26 of The Busy Tree.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Top is a multiple-meaning word. Here it means up high. Top can also mean a toy that spins.

section.rac_body-text: Have children pretend to be one of the animals on the Big Chart. Divide children into two groups: “pond animals” and “land and tree animals.” Have each group show their animals’ movements. For example, they can fly like a butterfly or a bird; dig like a worm; swim like a fish; or hop like a grasshopper or a frog.
Provide a writing prompt about animal homes and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children learn the sound and intonation of language by listening to you read aloud from various texts—from information to stories to poetry. Children can show off their new skills when they substitute new words in an old song (like “The Farmer in the Dell”), or when they anticipate the end of a line based on a rhyme pattern.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to pretend to be an animal from either At the Pond or The Busy Tree. Have children describe their animal homes and show how they would live in them. Encourage children to use describing words as they talk about their homes. They can use their arms to show how big or how high up their animal homes might be.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book The Busy Tree by Jennifer Ward.
Scout loves using new words. He collects words just like he collects acorns!
This week we read all about all the animals that live in and around one tree. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: If you could live in any animal home, which would you choose?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Now we know the things that happen in and around the tree. How is the tree busy?
Look at the tree. Part of it is under the ground. This part is called the roots.
Let’s pretend our toes are roots and our bodies are trees.
Look how the ants are all in a line. They march very quickly up the tree trunk.
Look at the animal in this picture. What animal is this? Where is the animal?
Look at the ladybug. Is it on the leaf or under the leaf?

Look at the children. The girl is pushing a boy on a swing that is on a tree. Do they look like they are having fun? Show me a thumbs up or thumbs down if you think they are. Ask 1–2 children to explain why they think the girl and the boy are having fun.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: If you could live in any animal home, which would you choose?
section.rac_body-text: Give one moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to pick 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I would live in a hole in the ground.
I would live in a nest in a tree.
I would live in a pond.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about animal homes and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Would you live in a tree or in a pond?
I would live in a tr_____ (tree).
I would live in a tree.
What do you like best about the animal home you chose?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Focusing attention is a key executive function skill. Children might need help paying attention at the end of a long week. To help children attend to your directions, eliminate distractions by making sure toys have been put away in the story-time space and by limiting background noise. Then, offer encouragement and praise children’s efforts.
